title.value: Multivariate analytical approaches for investigating brain-behavior relationships.
title.justification: This is the title listed in the PUBLISHED section mentioning the title and scientific journal.
title.quote: Multivariate analytical approaches for investigating brain-behavior relationships.

extractions.description: This study investigates how different multivariate statistical approaches, namely canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC), and partial least squares regression (PLSR), can influence the interpretation of brain-behavior relationships, particularly in understanding psychopathology dimensions in children using data from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study.

type.justification: The study uses data from 9,027 children to empirically investigate brain-behavior relationships through different multivariate analytical methods.
type.quote: The present analyses exemplify how the differences between alternative multivariate analytical approaches may influence research findings and their corresponding interpretations in the context of studying brain-behavior relationships.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on brain-behavior relationships and the analysis of neural substrates.
name.quote: The purpose of this study was to exemplify how the choice of multivariate approach can change brain-behavior interpretations.

name.justification: The study specifically looks at how different dimensions of psychopathology relate to brain structure in children.
name.quote: We examined the associations between psychopathology dimensions including general psychopathology, attention-deficit/hyperactivity symptoms, conduct problems, and internalizing symptoms with regional brain volumes.

name.justification: CCA is one of the three analytical models used in the study to explore brain-behavior relationships.
name.quote: We used data from 9,027 9- to 10-year-old children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive DevelopmentSM Study (ABCD Study®) to examine brain-behavior relationships with three commonly used multivariate approaches: canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC), and partial least squares regression (PLSR).

is_contributed.justification: CCA is a general method and not a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: The most commonly employed multivariate analytical approaches in the study of brain-behavior relationships are canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC) analysis, and partial least squares regression (PLSR) analysis.

is_executed.justification: The execution environment of the model is not specified in the paper.
is_executed.quote: Using all three approaches, we examined how the relationships between GMV and psychopathology in children may differ or converge based on the method used.

is_compared.justification: The CCA model is compared with the other multivariate models (PLSC and PLSR) in the study.
is_compared.quote: The present analyses exemplify how the differences between alternative multivariate analytical approaches may influence research findings and their corresponding interpretations in the context of studying brain-behavior relationships.

referenced_paper_title.value: Relations between two sets of variates
referenced_paper_title.justification: Hotelling, H. (1992) is referenced as a significant paper for CCA.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In CCA, the goal is to find a pair of linear transformations, one representing each set of variables, such that the variables are maximally correlated in the transformed (embedding) space (Hotelling, 1992).

name.justification: PLSC is one of the three analytical models used in the study to explore brain-behavior relationships.
name.quote: We used data from 9,027 9- to 10-year-old children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive DevelopmentSM Study (ABCD Study®) to examine brain-behavior relationships with three commonly used multivariate approaches: canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC), and partial least squares regression (PLSR).

is_contributed.justification: PLSC is a general method and not a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: The most commonly employed multivariate analytical approaches in the study of brain-behavior relationships are canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC) analysis, and partial least squares regression (PLSR) analysis.

is_executed.justification: The execution environment of the model is not specified in the paper.
is_executed.quote: Using all three approaches, we examined how the relationships between GMV and psychopathology in children may differ or converge based on the method used.

is_compared.justification: The PLSC model is compared with the other multivariate models (CCA and PLSR) in the study.
is_compared.quote: The present analyses exemplify how the differences between alternative multivariate analytical approaches may influence research findings and their corresponding interpretations in the context of studying brain-behavior relationships.

referenced_paper_title.value: Partial least squares (PLS) methods for neuroimaging: a tutorial and review.
referenced_paper_title.justification: Krishnan, A et al. (2011) is referenced as a significant paper for PLSC.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In PLSC, two datasets are correlated by identifying which data co-occurs and finding pairs of latent vectors with maximal covariance (Krishnan et al., 2011).

name.justification: PLSR is one of the three analytical models used in the study to explore brain-behavior relationships.
name.quote: We used data from 9,027 9- to 10-year-old children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive DevelopmentSM Study (ABCD Study®) to examine brain-behavior relationships with three commonly used multivariate approaches: canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC), and partial least squares regression (PLSR).

is_contributed.justification: PLSR is a general method and not a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: The most commonly employed multivariate analytical approaches in the study of brain-behavior relationships are canonical correlation analysis (CCA), partial least squares correlation (PLSC) analysis, and partial least squares regression (PLSR) analysis.

is_executed.justification: The execution environment of the model is not specified in the paper.
is_executed.quote: Using all three approaches, we examined how the relationships between GMV and psychopathology in children may differ or converge based on the method used.

is_compared.justification: The PLSR model is compared with the other multivariate models (CCA and PLSC) in the study.
is_compared.quote: The present analyses exemplify how the differences between alternative multivariate analytical approaches may influence research findings and their corresponding interpretations in the context of studying brain-behavior relationships.

referenced_paper_title.value: PLS-regression: a basic tool of chemometrics
referenced_paper_title.justification: Wold, Sjöström, & Eriksson (2001) is referenced as a significant paper for PLSR.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Finally, PLSR, the only clearly predictive method among the three, fits a linear regression model by projecting each set of variables into a latent space and maximizing the covariance structures in these two spaces (Wold et al., 2001; Krishnan et al., 2011).

name.value: Adolescent Brain Cognitive DevelopmentSM Study (ABCD Study®)
name.justification: The dataset from the ABCD Study® is used extensively for the analysis conducted in the paper.
name.quote: We used data from 9,027 9- to 10-year-old children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive DevelopmentSM Study (ABCD Study®) to examine brain-behavior relationships with three commonly used multivariate approaches.

referenced_paper_title.value: The ABCD Study: A Major Resource for Cognitive Neuroscience
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides background information on the ABCD study dataset used in this research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The current study used data from Wave 1 (release 4.0) of the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study (Volkow et al., 2018), which includes data from 11,876 children from 9 to 10 years of age.

name.justification: The scikit-learn library is explicitly mentioned as being used for performing the multivariate analyses.
name.quote: The CCA, PLSC, and PLSR were performed using the scikit-learn program in Python.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides detailed information on the library used for the analysis in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The CCA, PLSC, and PLSR were performed using the scikit-learn program in Python.2
